docinfo.docinfo:doc-heading: PART 54 ADMINISTRATION OF ESTATES AND EXECUTION OF TRUSTS [rr 54.1–54.8]

heading.title: PART 54 ADMINISTRATION OF ESTATES AND EXECUTION OF TRUSTS [rr 54.1–54.8]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: PART 54 ADMINISTRATION OF ESTATES AND EXECUTION OF TRUSTS [rr 54.1–54.8]

leg:heading.title: ADMINISTRATION OF ESTATES AND EXECUTION OF TRUSTS [rr 54.1–54.8]

p.text: [Pt 54 insrt Amendment 17 of 2007 r 2 and Sch 1[7], effective 5 October 2007]

entry.emph: Administration of estates and execution of trusts — Rules 54.1–54.8

row.entry: This part allows proceedings to be brought to determine questions of law or interpretation involved in the administration of estates and trusts.

UCPR r 54.1 defines “administration proceedings” as proceedings in the Supreme Court involving the administration of an estate or the execution of a trust. It necessarily follows that the present Part applies only to proceedings in the Supreme Court.
The rules substantially replicate, with some modifications, the former SCR Pt 68. Those provisions were themselves derived from the Equity Act 1901.
Directions relating to the trust or estate ‥ [54.3.30]
Questions arising in administration of trust ‥ [54.3.10]
Relief that may be granted ‥ r 54.5
Sale of trust or estate property ‥ r 54.8

p.text: In this Part:
means proceedings for the administration of an estate, or for the execution of a trust, under the direction of the Supreme Court.
means proceedings brought pursuant to rule 54.3.
means a deceased person’s estate.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 54.2] r 54.2 Application of Part (cf SCR Part 68, rule 3)

leg:heading.title: Application of Part (cf SCR Part 68, rule 3)

p.text: This Part applies to both administration proceedings and ancillary proceedings.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 54.3] r 54.3 Relief without general administration (cf SCR Part 68, rule 2)

leg:heading.title: Relief without general administration (cf SCR Part 68, rule 2)

p.text: Proceedings may be brought for any relief which could be granted in administration proceedings.
Proceedings may be brought for the determination of any question which could be determined in administration proceedings, including:
any question arising in the administration of an estate or in the execution of a trust,
any question as to the composition of any class of persons:
having a claim against an estate, or
having a beneficial interest in an estate, or
having a beneficial interest in property subject to a trust,
any question as to the rights or interests of a person who claims:
to be a creditor of an estate, or
to be entitled under the will, or on the intestacy, of a deceased person, or
to be beneficially entitled under a trust.
Proceedings may be brought for an order directing any executor, administrator or trustee:
to furnish accounts, or
to verify accounts, or
to pay funds of the estate or trust into court, or
to do or abstain from doing any act.
Proceedings may be brought for:
an order approving any sale, purchase, compromise or other transaction by an executor, administrator or trustee, or
directing any act to be done in the administration of an estate that the Supreme Court could order to be done if the estate were being administered under the direction of the Court, or
directing any act to be done in the execution of a trust that the Supreme Court could order to be done if the trust were being executed under the direction of the Court.
Subrules (1)–(4) do not limit the operation of each other.
In any proceedings brought pursuant to this rule, a claim need not be made for the administration of the estate, or the execution of the trust, under the direction of the Supreme Court.

level.toc-caption: [54.3.5] Parties claiming adversely to the estate

heading.title: Parties claiming adversely to the estate

p.text: It is not within the jurisdiction under this Part to decide questions against parties claiming adversely to the estate as such could not occur in an administration suit except by consent: Re Davies (1888) 38 Ch D 210 ; Re Giles (1890) 43 Ch D 391 at 398 ; Evans v Evans (1910) 10 SR (NSW) 594 ; Hudson v Gray (1927) 39 CLR 473 at 502; 1 ALJR 1266 .

level.toc-caption: [54.3.10] Questions arising from the administration or execution of a trust (Subrule (2)(a))

heading.title: Questions arising from the administration or execution of a trust (Subrule (2)(a))

p.text: Questions arising in the administration of a trust include questions as to who is entitled to receive payment or distribution of trust money or property including all necessary disputed or doubtful matters affecting the construction or operation of the trust instrument: Augustus v Permanent Trustee Co (Canberra) Ltd (1971) 124 CLR 245 at 253–54; [1971] ALR 661; BC7100160 .

Subrule (2)(a) includes questions as to whether a trustee should do in an emergency acts which he has no power to do without sanction of the court: Re New [1901] 2 Ch 534 ; Re Tollemache [1903] 1 Ch 955 ; Re Crago (1908) 8 SR (NSW) 269 ; McCarthy v McCarthy Pty Ltd (1919) 19 SR (NSW) 122 ; Templeton v Leviathan Pty Ltd (1921) 30 CLR 34; 28 ALR 95; BC2100001 ; Re Downshire [1953] Ch 218; [1953] 1 All ER 103 , cf Re Stephenson (1906) 6 SR (NSW) 420 at 425 ; Brown v Brown (1924) 24 SR (NSW) 495 ; Gonzales v Claridades (2003) 58 NSWLR 211; [2003] NSWCA 227; BC200304834 .

The ascertainment of a class of beneficiaries is usually called a next of kin enquiry. As to form of order for such an enquiry, see Re Bullock [1945] VLR 111; [1945] ALR 139 . An unsuccessful claimant is normally not allowed his costs out of the estate: Sheil v Doneley (1903) 3 SR (NSW) 60 . In general, see Re Forrest (1913) 35 ALT 73.

As to legitimacy, there is a strong presumption in favour of the valid marriage of persons who have lived together as man and wife which can only be rebutted by the most cogent evidence: Re Hamer [1937] 1 All ER 130 ; Re Taplin [1937] 3 All ER 105 ; Jacombe v Jacombe (1961) 105 CLR 355 at 360; [1961] ALR 788; BC6100770 ; Persian v Persian [1970] 2 NSWR 538 at 543–46; [1971] ALR 578 ; Re Pennington (No 2) [1978] VR 617 .

Subrule (2)(c) includes claims for disputed debts: Re Powers (1885) 30 Ch D 291 ; the capital value of an annuity: Re Hargreaves (1890) 44 Ch D 236 ; Re Pink [1927] 1 Ch 237 , and as to whether a debt is satisfied by a legacy: Fitzgerald v National Bank [1929] 1 KB 394; [1928] All ER Rep 596 .
Subrule (3)(c) probably only applies to moneys actually in the trustee's hands: Nutter v Holland [1894] 3 Ch 408 ; Re Clinton (1910) 10 SR (NSW) 465 .

level.toc-caption: [54.3.30] Directions relating to the trust or estate

p.text: Legislation cited in [54.3.30] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 54.3(3)(d).

heading.title: Directions relating to the trust or estate

p.text: Legislation cited in [54.3.35] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 UCPR 54.

The power of the Court to make determinations in administration proceedings pursuant to Rule 54 UCPR 54 (sometimes referred to as “the originating summons facility”) and the statutory procedure for trustees to obtain the court’s “opinion, advice or direction” (under s 63 of the Trustee Act 1925) have some similarities. The interaction between them was discussed by the High Court in Macedonian Orthodox Community Church St Petka Inc v His Eminence Petar The Diocesan Bishop of Macedonian Orthodox Diocese of Australia and New Zealand (2008) 237 CLR 66; 249 ALR 250; [2008] HCA 42; BC200807738 ("the Macedonian Church Case "). Despite remarking on the similarity (at [43], [44] & [49] the High Court highlighted the distinction that the UCPR r 54 procedures operates more directly in a context where affected parties are likely to be joined as interested parties. On the other hand, the primary function of the procedures under s 63 of the Trustee Act is to permit the Court to provide private advice to trustees (despite notice to potentially affected persons and limited participation in the proceedings): see the Macedonian Church Case at [61]–[65]. Each procedure not only provides a protection against subsequent complaint by affected persons but also protects the trustee from personal liability for costs incurred: Macedonian Church Case at [45].”
Legislation cited in [54.3.40] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court (Corporations) Rules 1999.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 64.

The present rule’s authority to commence proceedings for relevant relief does not limit the court’s power to grant that relief in other proceedings: see, for example, Re Bevillesta Pty Ltd [2011] NSWSC 1378; BC201108900 at [19]–[34] ; (proceedings involving a “creditors’ trust” created by deed of company arrangement — commenced by interlocutory process under the Supreme Court (Corporations) Rules 1999 (NSW) — directions made pursuant to s 64 CPA facilitating amendment of the process to be dealt with under the court’s general equitable jurisdiction).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 54.4] r 54.4 Claim under judgment (cf SCR Part 68, rule 6)

leg:heading.title: Claim under judgment (cf SCR Part 68, rule 6)

p.text: If, in the taking of an account of debts or liabilities under an order in proceedings relating to an estate or trust, a person who is not a party to the proceedings makes a claim:
no party (other than an executor or administrator of the estate or a trustee under the trust) is entitled to appear in relation to the claim except by leave of the Supreme Court, and
the Supreme Court may direct or allow any party to appear, either in addition to or in substitution for the executors, administrators or trustees.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 54.5] r 54.5 Relief that may be granted (cf SCR Part 68, rule 7)

leg:heading.title: Relief that may be granted (cf SCR Part 68, rule 7)

p.text: The Supreme Court may make any certificate or order and grant any relief to which the plaintiff is entitled by reason of a defendant’s breach of trust, wilful default or other misconduct.
Subrule (1) does not affect the power of the Supreme Court under rule 6.6.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 54.6] r 54.6 Supreme Court not required to order general administration (cf SCR Part 68, rule 8(1))

leg:heading.title: Supreme Court not required to order general administration (cf SCR Part 68, rule 8(1))

p.text: The Supreme Court need not make an order for the administration of an estate, or for the execution of a trust, under the direction of the Court unless the order is necessary for the determination of the questions arising between the parties.

Formerly orders for the general administration of a trust were made as of course when sought by a trustee or beneficiary: Underhill On Trusts 9th ed 491; Re Blake (1885) 29 Ch D 913 at 916 ; Ewing v Orr Ewing (1883) 9 App Cas 34 . However, the procedure of a general administration became so characterised by unacceptable delay and expense that legislative changes were made that were designed to encourage the resolution of disputes by means other than the making of orders for general administration: s 11 of the Supreme Court Procedure Act 1900; s 11 of the Equity Act 1901, Pt 68 of the Supreme Court Rules 1970. An order for general administration will not now be made if the matters in issue can be disposed of without such an order: Re Wilson (1885) 28 Ch D 457 ; Re Blake (1885) 29 Ch D 913 ; Heydon v Gell (1900) 21 LR (NSW) Eq 265 . Nevertheless, the present rules clearly contemplate the making of an order for general administration in an appropriate case: see r 54.7; Hyman v Permanent Trustee Co of New South Wales Ltd (1914) 14 SR (NSW) 348 (recurrent difficulties of valuation in a trust for partition); Re Flavelle [1969] 1 NSWR 361 (numerous long standing breaches of trust); McLean v Burns Philp Trustee Co Pty Ltd (1985) 2 NSWLR 623; 9 ACLR 926 .

The court will not even embark upon particular enquiries with or without a general order for administration unless it is necessary and proper to do so: Sanders v Sanders (1914) 15 SR (NSW) 21 ; Norman v Corrigan (1916) 16 SR (NSW) 225 at 231 . It will not be a proper case for an enquiry where the possible result would be that the whole fund would be spent in costs: Re Customs and Excise Officers Mutual Guarantee Fund [1917] 2 Ch 18 at 26–7 and see Meredith v Davis (1933) 33 SR (NSW) 334 (enquiry sought by a person on legal aid).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 54.7] r 54.7 Supreme Court may order general administration in certain circumstances (cf SCR Part 68, rule 8(2))

leg:heading.title: Supreme Court may order general administration in certain circumstances (cf SCR Part 68, rule 8(2))

p.text: This rule applies if it appears to the Supreme Court that an order for the administration of an estate or the execution of a trust under the direction of the Court is necessary:
to prevent proceedings by any person who claims:
to be a creditor of the estate, or
to be entitled under the will, or on the intestacy, of the deceased, or
to be beneficially entitled under the trust, or
to protect the interests of any person who is, or who may be, beneficially entitled under the trust.
In these circumstances, the Court:
may make such an order, and
may further order that no steps are to be taken under the order, or under any account or inquiry directed, without the leave of the Court.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 54.8] r 54.8 Conduct of sale (cf SCR Part 68, rule 9)

leg:heading.title: Conduct of sale (cf SCR Part 68, rule 9)

p.text: If the Supreme Court makes an order:
for the sale of property comprised in an estate, or
for the sale of trust property,
then, unless the Court otherwise orders, the executors, administrators or trustees, as the case requires, are to have the conduct of the sale.
